condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: 1.4: Relevant government ministries at central, provincial and municipal levels have enhanced capacity to design, cost, monitor and report on policies and strategies of social service packages, for girls and boys (0–59 months) and pregnant women, especially in targeted, deprived areas.

description.narrative: UNICEF has continued to provide technical support and advocate for policy change through, generating evidence on the situation of most vulnerable children and promising practices to address systematic challenges, promoting south-south cooperation, supporting the Government of Angola in mobilizing resources for critical programmes and to mitigate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:27/08/2020

title.narrative: % of municipalities implementing the national strategy to prevent stunting in children.
% of education budget allocation to Early Childhood Education (not including iniciao at primary schools).
System Strengthening - Early learning - Existence of national policy, leadership and budget for early learning - score (1-4), see guidance
Number of provinces with preschool technical units adequately funded and staffed.

Existence of legislation prohibiting all forms of corporal punishment of children, by setting (all settings, and by setting: home, schools, alternative care settings and day care, as a disciplinary measure in penal institutions/detention, and as a sentence for an offence)
Existence of national social protection policy and strategy.
Existence of water, sanitation and hygiene sector planning mechanism
Policy for home visits of new-borns is developed and/or revised, adopted and in use.
Policy on focused antenatal care has been developed, adopted and implemented.
Education systems are implementing a minimum package of interventions to promote learning outcomes including early learning
Existence of supply to provide two annual doses of vitamin A supplements to all children aged 6-59 months.
